bibl.title: Case history of Jose Antonio Viviesca by Roberto Serpa, translated by Frederick A. Miller, [1923]

div1.p: The case history describes Viviesca's final illness and his autopsy.

div1.head: Case history of Jose Antonio Viviesca by Roberto Serpa, translated by Frederick A. Miller, [1923]
div1.p:
Jose Antonio Viviesca, 28 years of age, citizen of Piedacuesta
and living in Rionegro where he had been working for more than five years
as a day laborer on various haciendas.

Past history negative as heriditary diseases. The data which
refers to the beginning and the evolution of the present illness are as
follows:

On the afternoon of the fifteenth (15th) of July the patient com-
plained of headache, fever, diarrhea, vomiting nor could he stand on his
feet or rest in bed as he had lost his sense of equilibrium.

On the two following days 16 & 17 the symptoms were increased and
black vomiting set in as well as black stools. On account of this it was
determined to send him to the hospital where he arrived on the morning of
the 18th at 10.00 A.M. Immediately on arrival at hospital he was placed
in bed under a mosquito net.

Physical examination at this time showed a subicteric color more
marked in the conjuctivae; anxious and shallow breathing; depositions of
black vomit at the corners of the mouth; traces both black and haemorrhagic
in the nostrils and the gums receded from the teeth and bloody. Axillary
temperature 40 C. Pulse filiform and weak. At that time no further examina-
tion was made. The patient entered into agony accompanied by convulsions and
expired in a few moments or a few hours (2) after having arrived in the village,
(Rionegro) or at twelve oclock on the day 18th of July.

At four oclock of the same day an autopsy was performed showing
the following:

The subictericic tint had become frankly ictericic. The sub-
cutaneous tissues were well colored yellow. On opening the abdominal
2
cavity the intestines were found greatly distended and congested in the
upper part. The stomach contained a great amount of black blood. The
mucosa of the stomach showed a great number of haemorrhagic plaques. The
liver, specimen of which is sent in bottle #1, was of normal size. Some
parts were dark red and others the color of “cafe con Leche”. On section
the borders of the cut showed haemorrhages.

The kidneys were greatly congested both on the surface and the
interior.
Translated from the report of Dr. Roberto Serpa.
